en:
_Last updated on {{1}}._

Pour le fran√ßais cliquez [ici](https://613covid.ca/fr/).

This website has forecasts of hospitalization counts from COVID-19 and wastewater recovery of SARS-CoV-2.

Website is optimized for desktop use. For mobile users, it is recommended to view in landscape mode.

Click here to access the COVID-19 Daily Dashboard created by Ottawa Public Health. The Ottawa Public Health dashboard provides up to date COVID-19 metrics that inform projections presented on this website.

en:
## Definitions

> **Hospital count** is the count of patients in all Ottawa hospitals at midnight on the previous day. OPH counts and hospital counts reported from other sources may be different because:

> * Hospital counts from other sources may include people who do not reside in Ottawa;

> * Interpretation of clearance may vary between hospitals and OPH;

> * Interpretation of treated for COVID-19 and being treated primarily for COVID-19 may vary slightly; and

> * OPH workload may delay the clearance of hospitalizations in preference to reporting new ones by OPH when volumes are high.

> **Transmission** is the risk that a person becomes infected when they come in contact with a person with COVID-19.

> **Doubling time** refers to the time it takes for the number of hospitalized patients to double in number. Conversely, **halving time** refers to the time it takes for the number of hospitalized patients to halve in number.

> **Daily growth** is the rate of change in the hospitalization from day-to-day.

> **Physical distancing** is a reduction in close contact between people.

> **Wise socializing** is ensuring you don't become a link in a COVID-19 transmission chain that ends in a person becoming hospitalized or dying. This involves wearing a mask in indoor spaces, isolating yourself from others when sick, staying 2 meters apart from people outside your household, and exercising proper hand hygiene. Click [here](https://www.ottawapublichealth.ca/en/public-health-topics/be-covidwise.aspx) for more details on being COVIDWise.

See the [More](/more) page for more definitions and more information about the terms used.

---
fr:
## D√©finitions

> **Le recensement des hospitalisations** correspond au nombre de patients recens√©s dans l‚Äôensemble des h√¥pitaux d‚ÄôOttawa √† minuit, le jour pr√©c√©dent.

> **La transmission** d√©signe le risque qu‚Äôune personne devienne infect√©e si elle est en contact avec une personne atteinte de la COVID-19.

> **Le temps de doublement** correspond au temps n√©cessaire pour que le nombre de patients hospitalis√©s double. √Ä l‚Äôinverse, **le temps de division** par deux indique le temps n√©cessaire pour que le nombre de patients hospitalis√©s diminue de moiti√©.

> **La croissance quotidienne** d√©signe le taux de variation du nombre d‚Äôhospitalisations jour apr√®s jour.

> **La distanciation physique** est la r√©duction du nombre de contacts √©troits entre les personnes.

> **L‚Äô√©tablissement avis√© de contacts sociaux s√©curitaire** consiste √† √©viter de devenir soi-m√™me un maillon d‚Äôune cha√Æne de transmission de la COVID-19 qui entra√Ænerait l‚Äôhospitalisation ou le d√©c√®s de quelqu‚Äôun. Vous devez donc porter un masque √† l‚Äôint√©rieur, vous isoler lorsque vous √™tes malade, garder une distance de 2 m√®tres avec les autres qui ne font pas partie de votre m√©nage et bien vous laver les mains. En savoir plus pour √™tre [COVID avis√©](https://www.santepubliqueottawa.ca/fr/public-health-topics/be-covidwise.aspx).

Consultez la section [Plus](/more) d‚Äôinfos pour en savoir plus sur les termes employ√©s.

---

en:
## Model use {#use}

There are two main uses of the projections:

1) Short-term projections (1 to 4 weeks) reflect the current level of COVID-19 transmission and current effectivess of ongoing COVID-19 prevention and control. Short-term projections the immediate need health care such hospital and critical care services for COVID-19 patients. 

2) Long-term projections (6 weeks onward) reflect sustain trends in COVID-19 transmissions. Long-term projections are helpful to assess the potiential effect of COVID-19 re-opening or the need of increased restrictions to control surges.

## Model accuracy {#accuracy}

Short-term projections have a moderate amount of variation between modelling methods. Countries such as [Germany and Poland](https://kitmetricslab.github.io/forecasthub/forecast) and the [United States](https://viz.covid19forecasthub.org) address model variation by aggregation and ensemble hubs that combine projections from different science teams and modelling approaches. The approach used at 613covid.ca is commonly found within ensemble hubs. Typically, the approach used at 613covid.ca generates projects that fall within the middle to somewhat higher than the average ensemble projection during increasing COVID-19 transmission or somewhat lower than average during decreasing COVID-19 transmission. 

Long-range projections have a lower accuracy than short-term projections as a consequence of changing COVID-19 control strategies. Long-term COVID-19 forecasting is similar to weather forecasting. It is difficult to predict when a hurricane will make landfall when it is still thousands of kilometers out at sea. Projections are updated with the latest data, including local data to help understand when and where the hurricane will reach landfall. 

We can't reliably forecast the weather six months out, and we can't forecast COVID-19 six months out. However, we can reliably forecast COVID-19 two to four weeks into the future. Those short-term projections give us time to plan and increase health-care resources as needed. 

That being said, hurricanes and COVID-19 are not the same. The path and force of a hurricane can't be influenced, but the worst effects of COVID-19 can be avoided if we follow public health guidelines like staying home and practive physical distancing. 

## Scenarios of physical distancing {#scenarios}

Physical distancing and other preventive measures susch as wearing masks are the most important factors for projecting long-range (1 to 4 months) COVID-19 cases and hospital use. 

Public Health Ontario projected 100,000 COVID-19 Ontario deaths with no preventative measures and a lower estimate of 3,000 deaths with preventive measures This wide range of estimates (100,000 to 3,000 deaths) reflects different levels of physical distancing. 

A high level of physical distancing will achieve a **97% reduction in deaths** compared to a scenario of no preventive action (100,000 deaths). The wide range in projections is why we need to monitor and update Ottawa projections to reflect how well we achieve COVID-19 prevention. 

## Physical distancing {#distancing}
fr:
## Utilisation des mod√®les {#use}

Les projections s‚Äôutilisent principalement de deux mani√®res : 

Les projections √† court terme (2 √† 4 semaines) servent √† conna√Ætre les besoins imm√©diats en services hospitaliers et en soins critiques pour les patients atteints de la COVID-19. 

Les projections √† long terme (6 semaines ou plus) servent √† √©valuer l‚Äôeffet d‚Äôun rel√¢chement de la distanciation physique. 

## Pr√©cision des mod√®les {#accuracy}

Il est difficile de faire des projections pr√©cises √† long terme sur la propagation de la COVID-19. C‚Äôest un peu comme tenter de pr√©voir le moment o√π un ouragan touchera terre alors qu‚Äôil est encore √† des milliers de kilom√®tres de la c√¥te. Les pr√©visions √† court terme sont plus pr√©cises. Il faut mettre √† jour les projections √† partir des donn√©es les plus r√©centes, notamment les donn√©es locales, pour avoir une meilleure id√©e du moment et de l‚Äôendroit o√π l‚Äôouragan touchera terre. 

Tout comme la m√©t√©o, il est impossible de pr√©dire l‚Äô√©volution de la COVID-19 avec fiabilit√© six mois d‚Äôavance. Par contre, nous pouvons pr√©dire de fa√ßon fiable l‚Äô√©volution de la COVID-19 pour les deux √† quatre prochaines semaines. Gr√¢ce √† ces projections √† court terme, nous avons le temps de pr√©voir les besoins en ressources pour offrir des soins de sant√© et d‚Äôaugmenter ces ressources si n√©cessaires. 

Cela dit, la COVID-19 et un ouragan sont deux choses diff√©rentes. Nous ne pouvons pas modifier la trajectoire ni la force d‚Äôun ouragan, mais nous pouvons √©viter les cons√©quences les plus graves de la COVID-19 si nous suivons les directives de sant√© publique, comme rester √† la maison et pratiquer la distanciation physique. 

Quant aux projections √† long terme relatives √† la COVID-19, elles nous informent sur l‚Äôefficacit√© de la distanciation physique et des autres mesures de pr√©vention. 

## Sc√©narios de distanciation physique {#scenarios}

La distanciation physique et les autres mesures pr√©ventives sont les facteurs les plus importants qui servent √† pr√©dire √† long terme (de 1 √† 10 mois d‚Äôavance) le nombre de cas de COVID-19 et l‚Äôoccupation des h√¥pitaux. 

Selon les projections de Sant√© publique Ontario, l‚Äôabsence de mesures de pr√©vention pourrait entra√Æner 100 000 d√©c√®s attribuables √† la COVID-19 en Ontario, tandis qu‚Äôavec des mesures de pr√©vention, le nombre estim√© de d√©c√®s est r√©duit √† 3 000. L‚Äô√©cart important entre les estimations (100 000 d√©c√®s comparativement √† 3 000) refl√®te les diff√©rents degr√©s de distanciation physique envisag√©s dans les sc√©narios. 

Un degr√© √©lev√© de distanciation physique permettrait de r√©duire de 97 % le nombre de d√©c√®s par rapport √† un sc√©nario sans aucune mesure pr√©ventive (100 000 d√©c√®s). Compte tenu des grandes diff√©rences entre ces projections, nous devons surveiller et mettre √† jour les projections d‚ÄôOttawa afin qu‚Äôelles refl√®tent l‚Äôefficacit√© de nos mesures de pr√©vention. 

## Distanciation physique {#distancing}

en:
Physical distancing is the reduction of close contacts between people. Close contact is defined as being within two meters of another person. See [Ottawa Public Health](https://www.ottawapublichealth.ca/en/public-health-topics/social-distancing.aspx) for more information on recommendations. 

If a person who had close contact with 10 people per day before the COVID-19 pandemic now has close contact with three people per day, their physical distancing score is 70 percent. If they have contact with five people per day, their score is 50 percent. 

In these projection models, a 70 percent physical distancing scenario means that on average the people of Ottawa have reduced their close contacts by 70 percent. Some people, like essential workers, cannot reduce their number of close contacts.

See [model](/model#distancing) for a technical discussion about how physical distancing affects COVID-19 spread.
fr:
La distanciation physique consiste √† r√©duire le nombre de contacts √©troits entre les personnes. Se trouver √† moins de deux m√®tres d‚Äôune autre personne constitue un contact √©troit. Consultez le site Web de [Sant√© publique Ottawa](https://www.ottawapublichealth.ca/en/public-health-topics/social-distancing.aspx) pour en savoir plus sur les recommandations. 

Si une personne qui avait des contacts √©troits avec 10 autres personnes par jour avant la pand√©mie de COVID-19 se limite maintenant √† des contacts √©troits avec trois personnes par jour, sa note de distanciation physique est alors de 70 %. Si elle a maintenant des contacts √©troits avec cinq personnes par jour, sa note est de 50 %. 

Dans ces mod√®les de projection, un sc√©nario fond√© sur une distanciation physique de 70 % signifie que la population d‚ÄôOttawa a r√©duit ses contacts √©troits de 70 % en moyenne. Certaines personnes, comme les travailleurs essentiels, ne peuvent pas limiter leur nombre de contacts √©troits. 

Consultez la section [Mod√®le](/model#distancing) pour un expos√© technique des effets de la distanciation physique sur la propagation de la COVID-19.

en:
## Physical distancing effectiveness {#distancing-effectiveness}

Physical distancing effectiveness describes how fast COVID-19 spreads in Ottawa compared to if there was no physical distancing. It is a mathematical calculation based on the observed doubling time (growth) of the hospital census for the previous week.

Physical distancing effectiveness is different from other measures that describe the level of physical distancing, including [surveys](https://www.ottawapublichealth.ca/en/reports-research-and-statistics/la-maladie-coronavirus-covid-19.aspx) or [community movement statistics](https://www.gstatic.com/covid19/mobility/2020-04-17_CA_Mobility_Report_en.pdf). 

At the beginning of COVID-19 in Ottawa, new cases (and hospitalizations) doubled every 3 to 4 days. This means that five patients in the hospital on Monday for COVID-19 would increase to 10 patients on Thursday or Friday and then to 20 patients the following week. 

As people in Ottawa began to physical distance, the spread of COVID-19 slowed. Less illness meant fewer patients were admitted to the hospital. There was a slower growth or doubling time of patients in hospitals. 

If there is perfect or 100% physical distancing effectiveness, there would be no COVID-19 spread. A person with COVID-19 illness would not contact people who can become ill and their infection would not spread past their illness. After a few weeks, COVID-19 would be eliminated from Ottawa; no new patients would be admitted to hospital. The hospital census would gradually decrease as currently admitted patients recovered and were discharged.

Currently, hospital admissions are slower than the initial 3 to 4 days doubling time, but we have not yet eliminated all COVID-19 growth. Physical distancing effectiveness reflects the hospital census that we expect given the observed doubling time. 

Note that there is a lag of several weeks between the level of physical distancing and its effect on slowing the growth of COVID-19 illness. There is a further time difference between the onset of illness and hospitalization. Physical distance effectiveness has the same time lag from the onset of distancing to the benefit of distancing showing results in the calculation of physical distancing effectiveness. 

See [model](model#distancing).
fr:
## Efficacit√© de la distanciation physique {#distancing-effectiveness}

L‚Äôefficacit√© de la distanciation physique repr√©sente la vitesse √† laquelle la COVID-19 se propage √† Ottawa par rapport √† ce qu‚Äôelle serait sans distanciation physique. Pour d√©terminer cette efficacit√©, il faut effectuer un calcul math√©matique √† partir du temps de doublement observ√© (croissance) indiqu√© dans le recensement des hospitalisations de la semaine pr√©c√©dente. 

L‚Äôefficacit√© de la distanciation physique est diff√©rente des autres indicateurs qui refl√®tent le degr√© de distanciation physique, comme les [sondages](https://www.ottawapublichealth.ca/en/reports-research-and-statistics/la-maladie-coronavirus-covid-19.aspx) ou les [statistiques sur la mobilit√© de la population](https://www.gstatic.com/covid19/mobility/2020-04-17_CA_Mobility_Report_en.pdf). 

Au d√©but de l‚Äô√©closion de COVID-19 √† Ottawa, le nombre de nouveaux cas (et d‚Äôhospitalisations) doublait tous les 3 ou 4 jours. Cela signifie que s‚Äôil y avait cinq patients atteints de la COVID-19 √† l‚Äôh√¥pital le lundi, ce nombre augmentait pour atteindre 10 patients le jeudi ou le vendredi, et 20 patients la semaine suivante. 

Quand la population d‚ÄôOttawa a commenc√© √† pratiquer la distanciation physique, la propagation du virus a ralenti. La diminution de la propagation s‚Äôest traduite par une baisse du nombre de patients admis √† l‚Äôh√¥pital. La croissance, ou le temps de doublement, du nombre de patients hospitalis√©s a donc ralenti aussi. 

Si l‚Äôefficacit√© de la distanciation physique √©tait parfaite, c‚Äôest-√†-dire de 100 %, il n‚Äôy aurait aucune propagation de la COVID-19. Une personne atteinte de la COVID-19 n‚Äôaurait aucun contact avec d‚Äôautres personnes qui pourraient contracter la maladie. Par cons√©quent, l‚Äôinfection ne se propagerait pas au-del√† de la personne atteinte. Apr√®s quelques semaines, la COVID-19 dispara√Ætrait √† Ottawa et aucun nouveau patient ne serait admis √† l‚Äôh√¥pital. Les chiffres du recensement des hospitalisations baisseraient graduellement, √† mesure que les patients gu√©ris obtiendraient leur cong√©. 

√Ä l‚Äôheure actuelle, l‚Äôaugmentation des hospitalisations est moins rapide que le temps de doublement initial (qui √©tait de 3 ou 4 jours), mais nous n‚Äôavons pas frein√© compl√®tement la croissance du nombre de cas de COVID-19. L‚Äôefficacit√© de la distanciation physique refl√®te le recensement des hospitalisations auquel nous nous attendons en fonction du temps de doublement observ√©. 

Il est √† noter qu‚Äôil a un d√©calage de plusieurs semaines entre l‚Äôobservation d‚Äôun certain degr√© de distanciation physique et la manifestation de ses effets sur la croissance des cas de COVID-19. Il y a √©galement un d√©lai entre l‚Äôapparition de la maladie et l‚Äôhospitalisation. Il en va de m√™me pour l‚Äôefficacit√© de la distanciation physique : il faut tenir compte du m√™me d√©calage entre le d√©but de la distanciation physique et l‚Äôapparition des bienfaits de celle-ci dans le calcul de l‚Äôefficacit√© de la distanciation physique. 

Veuillez consulter la section [Mod√®le](model#distancing).
